note: Core weapons only. For pilot bonding, expanded melee, arena combat, salvage, and walker vs infantry rules, see the full Fang & Claw supplement.

vehicles.name: Scout Mech
vehicles.desc: Twenty tons, fast legs, and sensors that see further than her guns can shoot. She runs ahead of the lance, finds the enemy, and reports back before the shooting starts. If she's doing her job right, nobody knows she's there.
vehicles.notes: The starter scout is your beginner's reconnaissance mech. She teaches players that information wins battles. Her weapons are light — she fights only when cornered. Use her to introduce stealth and sensor mechanics before players graduate to heavier frames.

vehicles.name: Striker Mech
vehicles.desc: Light, fast, and built to hit and run. She carries medium weapons on a frame that trades armour for speed. She doesn't stand and fight — she dashes through the enemy formation, fires, and is gone before the return volley arrives.
vehicles.notes: The starter striker teaches hit-and-run tactics. She's fast enough to choose her engagements and fragile enough that choosing wrong is fatal. Perfect for players who like speed and risk.

vehicles.name: Battle Mech
vehicles.desc: The all-rounder. Fifty tons of balanced weaponry, adequate armour, and middling speed. She can fill any role in the lance without excelling at any of them, which makes her the most useful mech on any battlefield that doesn't have a specific requirement.
vehicles.notes: The starter battle mech is your default player machine. She does everything, handles well, and teaches the basics without punishing mistakes too harshly. Start new players here and let them specialise once they know what they enjoy.

vehicles.name: Assault Mech
vehicles.desc: Heavy armour, heavy guns, and the subtlety of a sledgehammer. She walks forward, fires everything, and dares the enemy to stand in her way. Speed is not her concern. Survival of anything in front of her is not her concern either.
vehicles.notes: The starter assault mech is the heaviest machine in the starter set. She hits hardest and takes the most punishment, but she's slow. Use her as the lance anchor — she holds the line while lighter mechs flank.

vehicles.name: Missile Boat
vehicles.desc: Every hardpoint carries missile racks. She fires salvoes that arc over terrain, saturating an area with explosives from behind the safety of a ridge. She never sees the enemy. She just makes their position untenable.
vehicles.notes: The missile boat teaches indirect fire. She needs spotters — scout mechs or drones — to designate targets. Without them she's useless. With them she's devastating. Use her to teach players that combined arms wins battles.

vehicles.name: Command Mech
vehicles.desc: Communications array, tactical display, and the software that turns four individual mechs into a coordinated lance. She carries fewer weapons because her real weapon is information — shared sensor data, coordinated fire plans, and the ability to see the whole battlefield at once.
vehicles.notes: The starter command mech teaches leadership mechanics. She boosts nearby allies and coordinates actions. Give her to the player who likes planning and tactics. Her survival is the lance's survival — she goes down and everyone fights alone.

vehicles.name: Quad Walker
vehicles.desc: Four legs, a stable weapons platform, and the tenacity of a bulldog. She doesn't fall over, she crosses rough ground without slowing, and her low profile makes her harder to hit than a biped. She's ugly and effective.
vehicles.notes: The quad walker teaches stability mechanics. She ignores knockdown effects and crosses difficult terrain at full speed. Use her for players who want reliability — she's not flashy, but she's always standing and always shooting.

vehicles.name: Jump Mech
vehicles.desc: Jet-assisted legs that launch her over buildings, walls, and anything else between her and the target. She lands hard, fires from unexpected angles, and jumps again before the enemy adjusts. Vertical movement changes everything.
vehicles.notes: The starter jump mech teaches three-dimensional combat. She goes over obstacles instead of around them. Use her in urban or mountain terrain where jump capability creates opportunities other mechs can't exploit. Count the fuel — jumps are limited.

vehicles.name: Anti-Air Mech
vehicles.desc: Rapid-fire weapons, tracking systems, and the reflexes to engage fast-moving aerial targets that other mechs can't hit. She protects the lance from air attack and makes enemy VTOL pilots deeply unhappy.
vehicles.notes: The anti-air mech teaches air defence mechanics. Without her, the lance is vulnerable to strafing runs. With her, enemy aircraft avoid the area. She's specialised — excellent against air targets, mediocre against ground units.

vehicles.name: Siege Mech
vehicles.desc: Demolition charges, reinforced limbs, and weapons calibrated to bring down structures rather than other mechs. She breaches fortress walls, collapses bunkers, and makes a hole that the rest of the lance charges through.
vehicles.notes: The starter siege mech teaches fortification mechanics. She's the answer to defended positions that the rest of the lance can't crack. Use her when the scenario involves a strongpoint that needs breaching. She's vulnerable to flanking while focused on the wall.
